Mr.
Y. F.
Wickliffe Rose
YELLOW FEVER: FEASIBILITY OF ITS ERADICATION
Introductory note.

In conference with General Gorgas soon after my return
to Washington in July our discussion turned to the sanitary needs
and responsibilities resulting from the opening of the Panama
Canal. Radical changes have been wrought in trade relations;
countries and ports between which there has been little or no
exchange are to be brought into close relation. Pest-holes of
infection that have been relatively harmless because of their
isolation are going to be on or near the world's highway of
commerce and travel. This calls for a new sanitary map of a
large region affected by the canal and for a new sanitary
program to meet the changed conditions. The canal is our
enterprise undertaken and carried through in the interest of
civilization; naturally we are interested in the new sanitary
responsibilities growing out of it.

I asked General Gorgas what he regarded as the more ur-
gent of these sanitary needs; and what, if anything, might be under-
taken with promise of definite and lasting results. He replied
without hesitation: “The control of yellow fever”.

He emphasized the menace of such endemic centers as Man-
aos and Guayaquil, referred to what has been done for Rio Janeiro,
Vera Cruz, Havana and Panama as demonstrating that the disease
can be stamped out in such centers, and finally expressed the
strongest confidence in its complete eradication as a feasible
undertaking.

In view of the anxiety which I have found throughout
the East on account of the possible introduction of yellow fever
into that region as a result of the Panama Canal, and in view of
General Gorgas' insistence as to the importance if the work and
as to the feasibility of its accomplishment, I have undertaken to
bring together and to exhibit in tentative outline the essential
facts concerning the present endemic centers of yellow fever and
the feasibility of undertaking its eradication. This summary
embodies the views of General Gorgas, Dr. Henry R. Carter and Dr.
J. H. White, who have cooperated in its preparation.
Wickliffe Rose.
YELLOW FEVER: FEASIBILITY OF ITS ERADICATION.

I. Known foci of yellow feverx The known foci of yellow
fever are:

1. Guayaquil, Ecuador, population 80,000, always
endemic.

2. Merida and Campecha, Yucatan, population 80,000 re-
garded as endemic and at present infected.

3. Manaos, Brazil. Manaos has a population of 50,000
and, like Guayaquil, is known as one of the worst centers in the
world. Para, population 200,000, endemic center of long standing,
at present suspected on account of relation to Manaos.

4. Perambuco and Bahia, Brazil. Pernambuco has a pop-
ulation of about 100,000 and Bahia a population of about 250,000. Known endemic centers.

5. La Guayra, Venezuela, and probably some other ports
on the south shore of the Caribbean. This area is a suspected
focus of infection and calls for investigation.

6. An African focus or group of foci on the West Coast
from Sierra Leone south to the Gulf of Guinea.

II. The menace of yellow fever. Yellow fever may spread upon
the introduction of infection into any area where there are non-
immune people and where the stegomyia mosquito is prevalent.
x See map and Exhibit A.

1. Distribution of the stegomyia. This mosquito is prev-
alent over practically all of the so-called “wet tropics and sub-
tropical regions of the globe,” a zone extending from about 38° north
latitude to 38° south latitude. (See map) The whole of this zone,
roughly speaking, may be considered “infectible territory”. The
stegomyia seems to prefer the coastal regions; it is not prevalent
in dry regions or in regions of high altitude.

2. Infection may be carried long distances. The infec-
tion in the mosquito seems to last all her life. The mosquito has
been known to live in captivity for 154 days. Two of Dr. Reed's
mosquitos transmitted yellow fever on the 57th day after biting an
infected person. Dr. Carter reports seeing yellow fever develop on
board a sailing vessel 68 days out from Rio, its last port.

The gradual disappearance of the wooden sailing ship tends
to lessen the danger of transporting infection. This was the car-
rier of yellow fever. The stegomyia bred in her tanks and water bar-
rels; if a case occurred on board, the ship was liable to transport
infected mosquitoes indefinitely. Ships of this type are still in
service. The steamer does not breed mosquitoes to any considerable
extent; but it does transport them. Its greater speed has
shortened enormously the passage between ports, and has thus
brought the foci of infection much nearer the free but infectible
areas.

Yellow fever was transmitted from Havana to Leghorn, Italy,
3
in 1804, and to France in 1861. From Brazil it was carried to
Lisbon in 1723; and again to Portugal in 1850, 1851 and 1856.

3. Menace to America. So far as our own country is con-
cerned, the fangs of yellow fever have been drawn. The eradica-
tion of the infection from Havana removed the chief source of
our danger. A case was reported two weeks ago in Texas, and
cases may continue to appear from time to time on our Southern
coast; but since the control of the recent epidemics in New
Orleans and Tampa the people of the states have lost their dread
of yellow fever as a scourge.

But in the countries south of us it is still the source
of constant anxiety. The east coast of Brazil, the Amazon valley,
the Caribbean region, and the west coast from Peru to Mazatlan,
Mexico, are subjec to invasion at all seasons. Throughout this
region yellow fever is the subject of constant vigilance on the
part of quarantine officers, and is a serious handicap to commerce
and to the general economic development of these countries.

4. Danger of transmitting yellow fever to the Orient.
The opening of the Panama Canal has so changed the trade relations
of some yellow fever foci as to increase the dangers of transporting
yellow fever to infectible territory now free. Manson in 1903
was especially insistent on the risk of conveying infection to
the Far East as a result of the opening of the Canal. Dr. James,
4.
of the India Medical Service, who was employed by his Govern-
ment to make a thorough investigation of the subject, is dis-
posed to regard Manson's statement as an exaggeration of the
danger; but he reports the real menace as sufficiently great to
call for a permanent uarantine force to be maintained at Panama
and at Hong Kong or Singapore at the expense of the English
colonies in the East. He recommends to the Indian Government
a systematic attack on the stegomyia mosquito.

Dr. J. J. Van Loghem, reporting on the subject in the in-
terest of the Netherlands East Indies, gives an impressive exhib-
it of facts to show that “so long as yellow fever exists in Amer-
ica the danger remains for Asia”. As a result of this report the
Government of the Netherlands addressed a communication to the
Government of the United States suggesting that our Government
take the initiative for the appointment of an international
commission for the purpose of elaborating a system of measures
to prevent the spread of yellow fever to the Pacific and South
Sea Islands by reason of the opening of the Panama Canal. Our
Government has communicated this suggestion to the governments
interested. The British government asks that action be postponed
until investigation into the habits of the stegomyia, undertaken
by the Imperial Bureau of Entomology, shall have been completed.
In the meantime I am advised by the Department of State that no
5.
further action seems likely during the present war in Europe.

Of Manson's anxiety for the East, Dr. Carter says: “I
think his opinion of the risk is exaggerated; yet I know that the
risk of conveyance to these countries is increased by the changes of
trade relations which will be thus brought about. Although I do
not count the risk of this conveyance great, yet the ill that
would follow if yellow fever was thus conveyed would be incalculable.
The epidemics resulting -- except in Japan -- would be uncontrolla-
ble; and I doubt if the disease would ever be eradicated from the
countries of southern Asia, which would thus be a continual menace
to the rest of the world. I count then that measures for the
eradication of yellow fever are especially advisable now on ac-
count of the opening of the Panama Canal. Especially are they
advisable in foci from which the risk of conveyance will be in-
creased by its opening.”

III. How yellow fever may be eradicated. The extermination of
yellow fever reduces itself to one essential thing: Destroying
the breeding places of the stegomyia mosquito in the endemic foci of
the infection.

1. Concentrate all effort on endemic foci. Endemic
centers are the seed-beds without which there can be no epidemics. If
these seed-beds be destroyed, the disease will disappear from all
other points. Fortunately these seed-beds are few in numbers. No small
6.
aggregation of people can furnish endemic conditions unless having
an abnormally large visiting list of non-immune traders or
tourists. This for the reason that a constant supply of non-
immune material is needed to maintain the infection of the mosquito.
The mosquito derives its infection only from infected persons, and
lives to carry this infection not longer than from 30 to 180 days.
In large cities the necessary supply of non-immune material is kept
up by the birth of large numbers of children as well as by the
advent of visitors. There are at precent but five or six known
endemic foci, and these are the only points that need attention.

2. To eradicate yellow fever in an endemic center concen-
trate all effort on exterminating the stegomyia mosquito. Dis-
regard the human host. Since two hosts, one human and one insect,
are necessary for the propagation of yellow fever, it is obvious
that perfect control of either is sufficient for the elimination
of this disease from a community.

The control of the human host involves: (1) early diagno-
sis of cases; and (2) protection of these cases by screening for
about four days from mosquitoes. But in endemic centers where ser-
ious outbreaks cannot occur and where the people, therefore, do not
fear the disease, it has been found impossible to discover and get
control of the cases in the early stages. Dr. Carter, referring
to Gorgas' work on the Isthmus, says: “The reason that the method
7
by control of the human host failed was because, under the con-
ditions that existed, it was impossible to carry it out. We could
not control the human host to the degree necessary for success.”
For Havana he states that only about one-eighth of the adult cases
were diagnosed; and, according to Gorgas, cases among native
children are practically never diagnosed. “I think”, says Dr.
Carter, “the most optimistic will admit that in such places con-
trol of the human host to a sufficient degree to eliminate yellow
fever is impossible - not difficult, but impossible. Our only hope
then, is to control the insect host, to destroy the stegomyia.”

3. Concentrate on breeding places. To exterminate the
stegomyia in any community destroy its breeding places. Fortunately
this is relatively easy. The stegomyia is a domestic mosquito;
it does not travel far and must live and breed near its human host.
It breeds only in artificial containers in clear water - cisterns,
rainbarrels, water-jars, tin-cans, etc. There is thus no necessity
for going afield, for draining marshes, for oiling ponds and streams.
We have simply to remove from the home premises all receptacles
which contain or may contain clear water long enough to breed
these mosquitoes. Where removal of such containers is impossible,
other measures such as screening to prevent their use as breeding
places may be adopted. This is the whole task; nothing else need

In order, therefore, to exterminate yellow fever we have
only to destroy the breeding places of the stegomyia in the
five or six endemic foci of infection.

4. Attack the foci separately. The map exhibits six
separate endemic foci or groups of foci. The one reason in favor
of simultaneous work in all centers is to prevent one focus just
cleaned up from becoming infected from another. But a study of the
map and of the commercial relations makes it clear that the
relations of these six groups of foci are such as to lessen the
danger of carrying infection from one to another. Moreover, when
a community has been freed from yellow fever by destroying its
stegomyia it can not be infected again so long as it is kept free
from the mosquitoes. All the centers in one group - as the towns
on the southern shore of the Caribbean - should be attacked
simultaneously. But an independent focus, like Guayaquil, or an
independent group, like the south shore group, may be dealt with
without reference to the others. The extermination of yellow fever
in one of these areas would be a permanent achievement, and would
be quite worth the doing even though no further work should be
undertaken. This has been demonstrated by the work done at Havana,
Rio Janeiro and Vera Cruz.

There are distinct advantages to be derived from working
these independent areas separately. It would give opportunity
to begin work on a small scale, say at the one most favorable
9.
point, and thus to try out working agencies and working methods.
As a result of experience at this one point the work would be
more effective at the next. There would be an advantage also in
being able to begin the work when one community is found willing
to have the work done and to assist in doing it. In the event
that any towns or countries should be hesitant about having the
work begun one or two effective demonstrations in other places
would probably change their attitude and secure the necessary
cooperation. To attack the endemic foci or groups of foci
separately is to follow the line of least resistance and of in-
creasing efficiency.

IV. Organization of working agency. Our experience in Havana
and the Canal Zone has demonstrated that yellow fever can be
eradicated in a given focus of infection by destroying the breed-
ing places of the yellow fever mosquito. The rapidity and
thoroughness with which the work can be done is a mere question
of efficiency in working machinery. General Gorgas, Dr. Carter
and Dr. White agree on the following type of organization where
local conditions permit:

1. A director: to be placed at the head of the work for
a given focus of infection; to be given authority under the general
supervision of the Commission and the local government to appoint
and dismiss subordinates and to make rules and regulations for the
10
conduct of the work: to be held responsible for results.

2. A corps of sanitary officers: One for each 20,000 in-
habitants or important fraction thereof; which responsible to the
Director and having under his immediate charge a group of sanitary
districts.

3. Under each sanitary officer five or six squads of in-
spectors, each squad under the direction of one of its members
who acts as foreman and has full charge of his squad, each member
of a squad to be assigned so many premises to keep free of mosqui-
toes by the various known methods; his work to be daily inspected
by the foreman of the squad; the work of the foreman in turn to be
under the supervision and constant inspection of the sanitary
officer.

The city to be divided into small sanitary districts; in
making this division consideration to be given to population local
conditions, convenience of administration; each district to be
assigned to one member of a squad of inspectors. The individual
inspector to go over his district once a week and see that no
mosquitoes are breeding on any premises; to see that all water
containers such as rain-barrels, tubs, buckets, jars, old tins,
etc. are properly cared for - destroyed, or regularly emptied and
scrubbed. The whole of this machinery to be so organised that the
records of detail work are brought each day under the inspection of
11.
V. Necessary administrative authority. There must be
authority to do this work - to inspect premises, to screen cisterns,
to empty water-jars, etc. This authority must be given by the
state or municipality. With proper ordinances passed, their en-
forcement will be largely a question of persistence and tact in
securing the cooperation of the people. But behind all voluntary
cooperation there must be recognised authority. General Gorgas
thinks adequate authority would probably be found in the existing
laws and sanitary regulations of the cities in which this work
needs to be done.

VI. Time required to do the work. Dr. Carter estimates that
to create the organization and to bring it to a state of working
efficiency will require from three to six months; and that to
complete the work from this point will require three to four
months more.

General Gorgas agrees that this is a liberal time allowance
for a community in which the Director of the work should be given
a free hand. In fact, he thinks with a free hand the work could
be done in a place like Guayaquil within six months. But in
actual practice he thinks it would probably be found necessary to
begin on a small budget, to work more slowly, and to take a longer
period of time within which to do the work. Taking all con-
tingencies into consideration two years would seem to be a safer
estimate of the time limit.

VII. Probable cost. Dr. White, basing his estimate on his ex-
perience in New Orleans, places the maximum cost at about $2.00
per capita for one year. One-fourth of this cost he attributes
to the item of handling cases. But in this work it is proposed
to have nothing to do with the handling of cases. This leaves the
annual per capita cost at about $1.50. At this rate the annual
budget for a city like Guayaquil with a population of 80,000
would be $120,000.

It is estimated that for a city having a population of
150,000 the annual per capita cost would probably drop to about
$1.25; and that for cities having a population of less than 50,000
it would increase accordingly.

In counting the cost the water supply may be a prime factor.
If one has to be introduced as a preliminary measure, the cost of
this may be large. A water supply in pipes contributes much to
the success of the work. When impossible to provide it, the situa-
tion can be turned by preventing access of mosquitoes to water
containers.

It would be expected in any case that a considerable propor-
tion of the cost would be borne by the state and local governments.
Just how far state and municipal governments can be relied upon to
supply funds for the work remains for negotiation with these govern-
ments to determine. Brazil contributed liberally to aid Rio Janeiro
13.
in getting rid of yellow fever; and for both Brazil and Rio
Janeiro the investment has paid and is still paying handsomely
in commercial returns.

It would seem that Ecuador and Guayaquil might be brought
to take the same view of similar work for that city. Guayaquil
is an important port. It is 3 1/2 days from Panama, now on the
world's highway. But no ship arriving at Panama from the docks
at Guayaquil is permitted to dock or to land passengers until the
end of the sixth day out from Guayaquil. This means that every
such ship is being held up at Panama for 2 1/2 days at a cost to the
company of from $300 to $1500 a day. And this not on one, but
on every journey to this port. And all this because Guayaquil
is an endemic center of yellow fever.x The economic handicap
to Ecuador and Guayaquil resulting from this condition in the past
has been enormous; the opening of the canal has made this handicap
much greater. The one simple fact that stamping out yellow
fever in Guayaquil would bring that port 2 1/2 days nearer Panama
would seem to make the cost of the work to either state or
municipality an insignificant item. It is estimated that in
similar manner the cost to commerce on account of quarantine
against yellow fever in Merida, Yucatan, is about $60,000 annually -
----------------------------------------------------------------------
x At present it has plague also.
14.
an amount sufficient in two years to stamp out yellow fever at
this point.

The situation just described exhibits also the interest which
steamship companies have in this work of eradicating yellow fever.
No disease provokes more prompt or more rigid quarantine than
yellow fever. The regular annual loss in money to the companies
whose ships call at these infected ports is enormous. The United
Fruit Company has found it good business to invest money in the
sanitation of their Central American ports of call. It would seem
not a vain expectation that the work properly organized and directed
would derive moral support, and, if necessary, financial aid, from
the navigation companies whose ships call at these infected ports.

If it should be found necessary to appeal to still other
agencies, there are influential boards of trade whose interests are
touched by the prevalence of yellow fever at important ports. And
there are the possibilities of strong appeal to the organized
medical interests, commercial interests, and humanitarian interests
of the countries in which the endemic centers of infection are
located. There is also the possibility of international agreement
on a plan of action having for its purpose the complete control or
eradication of the disease.

VIII. Where to begin Guayaquil and Manaos are known as the
two most dangerous seed-beds of yellow fever in the world. They are
regarded as the fountain heads from which the infection in many less
important places is being continually fed. General Gorgas, Dr. Carter
and Dr. White agree that if the cooperation of Guayaquil could be
secured, that city should be made the first point of attack. It
is the only focus of infection on the West Coast; it is a constant
menace to the canal and is the center from which the canal has
most to fear; it is the source of greatest danger to the Far East
and this danger has been greatly increased by opening the canal.
General Gorgas is especially insistent on making Guayaquil the
beginning point. He says, “I should be in favor of making a start
at Guayaquil and Manaos. Guayaquil first and Manaos second. And
as many secondary points as we had money for. But I would feel
great confidence that yellow fever would disappear of itself after
we once got Manaos and Guayaquil under control.”

This judgment as to the results of controlling infection in
these two points would seem optimistic; it is highly improbable
that infection is being kept up in West Africa or even in Yucatan
or the south shore of the Caribbean from Manaos or Guayaquil. But
this aside, Guayaquil, because of its isolation from other centers,
because of its greater menace and of its wide-spread reputation as
a pest hole of yellow fever is clearly the logical point of attack.

But there may be practical difficulties in the way of
making a beginning of the work at Guayaquil. Ecuador, we are
told, and especially the people of Guayaquil, do not like
Americans. Whether or not the city would contribute funds,
grant the necessary authority, or even permit the work to be
undertaken remains to be ascertained. The practical beginning
point is the community that offers conditions most favorable
for getting speedy and definite results.
Washington, D.C.
October 27, 1914.
